The Super Soldier Serum enhances all of the user's physical abilities to the peak of human potential. This includes strength, speed, durability, agility, reflexes, and healing.
In the MCU, Hydra, a secret organization that infiltrated many governments and organizations, has significantly influenced major historical events, including World War II and the Cold War. This clandestine group has been shaping history from the shadows, which diverges from our understanding of these historical periods.
Wakanda's history is deeply tied to a meteorite made of Vibranium that crashed into its territory thousands of years ago. The metal's unique properties allowed Wakanda to develop technology far beyond the rest of the world. 
The Bifrost Bridge serves as a controlled wormhole of sorts, allowing instantaneous travel between Asgard and the other realms.
In Avengers, time travel is used as a crucial strategy to undo the catastrophic events caused by Thanos.
By creating portals with the Sling Ring, Doctor Strange is able to move quickly through space, even crossing the Earth or entering other dimensions.
Heroes like Iron Man and Captain America are not only revered individuals, but they have also become cultural icons, serving as role models for both children and adults.
Ant-Man, or Dr. Hank Pym, is a brilliant scientist who discovered the subatomic "Pym particles," enabling him to alter his size.
The Black Panther can communicate with the spirits of past Panthers and ancestors in the Djalia, a spiritual plane. This connection underscores the importance of tradition and guidance in Wakandan society.
With his mighty hammer Mjolnir, Thor possesses immense strength and the ability to control weather.
Due to civilian casualties and destruction caused by superhero actions, the United Nations introduced the Sokovia Accords, requiring all superheroes to register and be subject to government oversight. 
S.H.I.E.L.D. was established with the initial purpose of addressing various supernatural and superhuman threats to protect the world from malevolent forces.
Steve Rogers, chosen for the Super Soldier Program, became Captain America to fight crucial battles against Hydra to stop them from using the Tesseract's energy for superweapon creation during World War II.
Wakanda's technology and prosperity primarily stem from a massive meteorite impact, rich in an extremely rare and powerful metal known as Vibranium.
One of Stark's major inventions, the arc reactor, is a clean, sustainable energy source that powers his Iron Man suits and Avengers Tower. This reactor harnesses the energy of a theoretically infinite loop, creating a miniaturized, high-output energy source that can last for years.
The Avengers often respond to threats as a small, cohesive team or even individually, making rapid decisions without the need for broader consensus or international cooperation.
The spaceship used by the Guardians of the Galaxy, such as the Milano, is equipped with faster-than-light engines and complex navigation systems, enabling them to move quickly through the universe.
In Avengers, a broad interstellar network is used by individuals and organizations to share, exchange, and access information.
Bruce Banner became the Hulk after an experiment exposed him to a massive dose of uncontrolled gamma radiation, drastically altering his biology with unforeseen consequences.

Human: Three astronauts who were stranded in space aboard the Skylab 2
(CNN) -- It's the stuff of nightmares -- being stranded all alone in space with just your crewmates for company and no way home, waiting on a hastily planned rescue.

For three American astronauts on board Skylab 2, that grim scenario nearly played out in 1973, 40 years ago this May, as NASA scrambled to design, build and launch an emergency space mission to come to their aid.

The United States' first space station only spent 24 months in orbit -- from 1973-1974 -- yet barfed astronauts, survived a near-disaster at launch, and helped train scientists in observing the sun without the pesky atmosphere getting in the way.

The three astronauts, Charles Conrad, Joseph Kerwin and Paul Weitz, were just three weeks into what was supposed to be an 84-day mission when disaster struck.

The story begins at the launch pad. Skylab was launched and then crewed almost a year before the horrific 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. While not involving human crew, Skylab's maiden launch proved that such accidents can and do happen.

When the 110,000-kilogram, 22,700-cubic-meter (730,000-cubic-foot) behemoth launched on May 14, 1973, the final stage of the Saturn rocket failed to disconnect properly at an altitude of 53 kilometers (175,000 feet). 

The astronauts were sent into space just 36 hours later, on a modified Apollo spacecraft mounted atop the very last Saturn rocket.

Shortly thereafter, at an altitude of 119 kilometers (390,000 feet), the jettisoning third-stage rocket pierced two delicate solar-panel wings, flipping Skylab end over end, and spewing thousands of pieces of debris that drilled thousands more small holes in the orbiting station.

The result was a massive temperature inversion -- the sunward-facing side was brought down to -122 degrees Celsius (-187.6 Fahrenheit), while the dark side soared to 221 degrees Celsius (430 Fahrenheit), according to NASA's account.

This risked killing the three astronauts before they even boarded the orbiting space station, and forced a massive overhaul on the flight plan.

After managing to dock with Skylab on their third try -- no mean feat considering the sheer size of the station, and its constantly spinning motion -- the crew entered to find the living quarters and entire structure simply too cold to survive.

They had to cover windows with makeshift blankets to halt the last of the cold air escaping into space, and activated an electrical heater to try and plan, somewhat bizarrely, a brass band.

That failed, and the astronauts instead decided to take bungee cords from their spacesuits and create impromptu electrical connections to deliver higher voltage electricity to the heater.

At this point, NASA realized that even if the trio were able to survive -- and mission control was clinging to hope that one of Skylab's faulty solar panels could still be deployed -- there was no way that they would have enough food, water, or oxygen to make it to day 85.

A rescue mission was ordered. A repair mission, to fix the solar panels and reopen one of the doors, would be tried first, but the short-lived Skylab would have to prepare to house as many as a dozen astronauts for an extended period by the end of the summer.

Despite its size, Skylab was cramped once the three astronauts arrived. The three were also the first people to experience "space sickness," and Conrad, the commander, at one point had to have part of his dinner boiled off upon learning that a fellow astronaut had vomited inside the space station.

In keeping with the "What could go wrong, will go wrong" theme, a vital canister holding waste collected by the astronauts got stuck, meaning that rather than simply chucking the thing out of the open airlock back into space, the astronauts had to manually wrestle the half-ton container free using hand tools and brute force.

Seven days before rescue could possibly have reached them even if it had been launched immediately, the astronauts were finally able to deploy the solar array, reopen the sealed hatch, and even set up a makeshift, two-man gym on the station's "Round Can."

Perhaps the strangest part of NASA's history of human spaceflight, Skylab caught the world's imagination, even serving as the basis for Richard Howard's 1974 suspense film "Hijack to the Stars."

Skylab's legacy is considerable: It served as the basis for Russia's Salyut space stations, as well as the International Space Station, and helped pave the way for future stint on the ISS by astronauts such as Buzz Aldrin.

Write highlights for this article

2. NASA quickly planned and launched an emergency rescue mission in 1973.
3. The crew overcame challenges, including extreme temperature inversion, oxygen depletion, and space sickness.
4. Skylab 2 marked the first time astronauts experienced "space sickness."
5. The station played a crucial role in advancing human spaceflight, laying the groundwork for subsequent space stations like Salyut and the International Space Station.
